f6_assessments.q0:
This is a great initiative! The problem itself is clearly outlined and the proposed solution can indeed address the problem. However, I do believe that there are three areas affecting the scale of impact that may benefit from a certain degree of re-evaluation, and they are:

1. The problem itself can be more succinctly defined. 
In the problem summary, the proposer stated that "Every nation needs a free and relevant education system - class and geopolitical circumstance define the type of education accessible". However, it's not clear what does a "free and relevant education system" entail, and why current education systems are not up to the task. This causes confusion for readers of the proposer as to what exactly is the problem that the team's trying to solve with the project: Is the target audience children? If so, what exactly is it that they're lacking under our current model of education that is in urgent need to be fixed? Is this problem specific to a specific country or region? Is this project a good-to-have-but-not-critical one, or is it really fixing something that dearly needs fixing?
Instead of saying that every country needs a free and relevant education system, explain what exactly in our current model of education is in need of urgent fixing. Be specific. For example, I can identify the problem as: mindless learning of students in countries with high-stake standardized testing (eg. China, Korea) where students forget what they learnt immediately after the exam has passed; they do not know why they're learning certain things and view learning only as a means to an end - achieving high marks in exams.

2. It's hard to pin down the unique selling point of the product as it's too broad.
The product seems to be trying to do a lot of things at once and as such, it confuses readers of the proposal on what exactly is the unique selling point of the product. i.e. why would people use this over the other competitors out there. When reading, I've been trying to actively look out for a unique selling point but can't see if it's the children-focused nature of the content, the interactivity of the content, emphasis on learning through gaming or anything else. This overlaps with the first point. Identifying a unique selling point would be ideal to cement dominant position in the market. 
Perhaps a good unique selling point would be the family-orientation. Instead of saying that this product is for both kids and adults, let's orient it as a playground for families (playground, because there is a suite of different sub-products like games, podcasts etc under it). Couple it with the interactivity across different medium and it'll be great.

3. Scalability.
From the proposal, it seems like the content creation will be primarily done by the team apart from the one for the kid's magazine. This model is not scalable. Instead, it might be good to experiment with other models - for example, by eventually positioning the product as a portable infrastructure for relevant content creators to reach the audience base that the product has gathered. This model is similar to how MOOC platforms like edX and Coursera are run. However, this links back to the point again: we need to be specific on who exactly our target audience is.

4. There's little contribution made to the development of the Cardano ecosystem.
Apart from launching the NFT collection on Cardano, there's little reference back to the usage of Cardano's infrastructure for this project. Furthermore, as the audience are largely in the Web2 world, having an NFT collection requires them to have a web3 identity which may be a hurdle to overcome for it to succeed. This requires some consideration. 

These are my two cents after reading through the proposal, hope it helps!
f6_assessments.q1:
Based on the founder's experiences as accomplished journalists and teachers, there is reason to believe that the team can deliver for the quality of content created given their ability to put themselves in the shoes of the audience to better see what would appeal to them. However, that's if the product is to remain primarily as a content creation and distribution medium. 
As stated earlier, the content creation model may not be scalable and an infrastructure model may do better to enhance scalability. However, if the suggestion has been taken, it's related more towards operations and logistics and less so for content creation. If that happens, a new team member with the relevant experiences may be necessary. 

In the short run, however, the team should still continue this model so as to build a dedicated audience base and establish itself as an incumbent in the space. As such, what is its unique selling point will need to be considered.
f6_assessments.q2:
As a content-creation platform, this is easily auditable as we can track the progress of the contents created and see if they're going as according to schedule, and easily audit the quality of content created. To assess the quality of the content created, a routine feedback mechanism may be good where feedbacks from the users can be collected and shown to the wider Catalyst community for accountability. 
The number of schools engaged will be a good metric too to measure the success of the proposal. However, it'd be better if the nature of engagement can be outlined in detail in the proposal as well - what will the engagement entail, how will it create more value for the students and if it's feasible to replace time for the main curriculum to this.
